I'm wondering if you would just for those who aren't yet familiar with Kiss the Ground as an organization or the movie, can you encapsulate for us what's the big deal about soil and why does that matter in the context of regeneration?
Kiss the ground is really imploring that we have this reverence for the substance that really makes life on earth possible.
I think soil is such an important thing to grasp for humanity to really see the regenerative future.
If you look at cultures, ancient cultures, indigenous cultures, having profound reverence and connection to the soil, the mother, the thing that gives them life.
the thing that gives them life, the things that protects them, gives them access to food, fertility and everything.
we've been drifting away from that faster and faster as humanity.
A lot of us understand that plants breathe out oxygen so that we can breathe.
the microbes in the soil use their enzymes in different processes to unlock nutrients in the soil and make those nutrients available for the plant to uptake in their roots.
the plant is literally dripping or leaking or exuding out of their roots into the soil. Why to feed microbes?
those organisms are made out of carbon because they ate the carbon that the plant fed them.
they evolved to make gluey substances made of carbon.
These sticky substances are made of carbon and bond our soil particles together, building aggregated healthy soil.
this big phenomenon called how much of those liquid sugars.

this process of plants pump it in, microorganisms turn it into these glues and store it as long-term stable carbon is what we really didn't understand or recognize in soil science until somewhere around 1996.
not just what our ancestors kind of knew intrinsically because of how they farmed and placed specific practices.
sticky substances are made of carbon and bond our soil particles together

plants pump it in
microorganisms turn it into these glues
turn it into these glues and store it as long-term stable carbon
we really didn't understand or recognize in soil science until somewhere around 1996
what our ancestors kind of knew intrinsically because of how they farmed and placed specific practices
the science has shown us how soil is actually forming
we can help nature to rebuild soil faster than we ever thought possible
